results.title: ‘How to throw a boomerang’ leaflet
results.brief_description: Yorta Yorta activist, artist and entrepreneur Bill Onus shared his culture as an act of resistance and reclamation of power. Through his factory and shop, Aboriginal Enterprises, he shared his art and culture, selling boomerangs and other pieces.

results.title: Sequins and sapphires
results.brief_description: Two of the most striking costumes on the big and small screens embody the glamour of leading First Peoples ladies.

constellations_primary.name: Sequins and sapphires
constellations_primary.description: Two of the most striking costumes on the big and small screens embody the glamour of leading First Peoples ladies.

results.description:
This form-fitting blue sequin dress worn by Julie (Jessica Mauboy) in The Sapphires (2012) is front and centre in the true story of an Indigenous singing group who entertained troops during the Vietnam War. It reflects late-1960s fashion and featured in the film’s posters and during critical scenes, including the fan-favourite performance of ‘Sugar Pie, Honey Bunch’ at the film’s end.

Equally as fabulous is the bright pink tinsel dress worn by Kitty (Elaine Crombie) in Kiki and Kitty (2017). As Kiki’s (Nakkiah Lui) fairy god-vagina, Kitty shimmers in this sensual, sequined ensemble and embodies all the repressed sass and sauciness of Lui’s buttoned-down lawyer.

“A vagina that came to life… was like someone who would essentially be my friend and who would stick up for me and they would wear sequins and drink martinis and just be all the things I kind of wish I was.” - Nakkiah Lui
description_for_label:
This form-fitting blue sequin dress worn by Julie (Jessica Mauboy) in The Sapphires (2012) is front and centre in the true story of an Indigenous singing group who entertained troops during the Vietnam War. It reflects late-1960s fashion and featured in the film’s posters and during critical scenes, including the fan-favourite performance of ‘Sugar Pie, Honey Bunch’ at the film’s end.

Equally as fabulous is the bright pink tinsel dress worn by Kitty (Elaine Crombie) in Kiki and Kitty (2017). As Kiki’s (Nakkiah Lui) fairy god-vagina, Kitty shimmers in this sensual, sequined ensemble and embodies all the repressed sass and sauciness of Lui’s buttoned-down lawyer.

“A vagina that came to life… was like someone who would essentially be my friend and who would stick up for me and they would wear sequins and drink martinis and just be all the things I kind of wish I was.” - Nakkiah Lui

results.title: Larger than life
results.brief_description: Two iconic Australian films. Two iconic Australian costumes.

constellations_primary.name: Dance sequins
constellations_primary.description: Looking at dance, ballroom, the Glitter Trilogy and the Red Curtain Trilogy.

results.description:
While most of the Oscar-winning costumes in The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert (1994) were made with small budgets and creative solutions like crafting glamorous outfits from cheap flip-flops, the pom-poms on this iconic wattle dress worn by Felicia JollyGoodFellow (Guy Pearce) were made by inmates at the Long Bay Correctional Complex.

In Baz Luhrmann’s Strictly Ballroom (1992), another Australian classic released two years earlier, sparkles are a must. Despite Australian Dancing Federation President Barry Fife’s (Bill Hunter) limited time on the dance floor, his sequined tuxedo shimmers and shines and helps bring what production and costume designer Catherine Martin calls the film’s “marvellous preposterousness” to life.
description_for_label:
While most of the Oscar-winning costumes in The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert (1994) were made with small budgets and creative solutions like crafting glamorous outfits from cheap flip-flops, the pom-poms on this iconic wattle dress worn by Felicia JollyGoodFellow (Guy Pearce) were made by inmates at the Long Bay Correctional Complex.

In Baz Luhrmann’s Strictly Ballroom (1992), another Australian classic released two years earlier, sparkles are a must. Despite Australian Dancing Federation President Barry Fife’s (Bill Hunter) limited time on the dance floor, his sequined tuxedo shimmers and shines and helps bring what production and costume designer Catherine Martin calls the film’s “marvellous preposterousness” to life.

results.title: The Last Emperor costumes
results.brief_description: These costumes from The Last Emperor enliven the Imperial court with rich reds that bring grandeur to the screen, a sense that’s reinforced by 9,500 extras who appear to be draped in delicately embroidered silk thanks to screen-printed rayon.

constellations_primary.name: Power and privilege, monarchy and make-up
constellations_primary.description: The upper echelons of society explored through colour, make-up and scandal.

results.description:
Colour had well and truly arrived in cinema by the time The Last Emperor (1987) was released, but its use in the film’s costumes and cinematography was Oscar-winning.

The film follows Pu Yi’s transition from the last emperor of China to ordinary citizen, and colour is essential to his journey. Deep crimson and orange hues capture both the majesty and the innocence of his childhood in the Forbidden City, while grey saturates his moments in jail later in life.

These costumes, by James Acheson, enliven the Imperial court with rich reds that bring grandeur to the screen, a sense that’s reinforced by 9,500 extras who appear to be draped in delicately embroidered silk thanks to screen-printed rayon.
description_for_label:
Colour had well and truly arrived in cinema by the time The Last Emperor (1987) was released, but its use in the film’s costumes and cinematography was Oscar-winning.

The film follows Pu Yi’s transition from the last emperor of China to ordinary citizen, and colour is essential to his journey. Deep crimson and orange hues capture both the majesty and the innocence of his childhood in the Forbidden City, while grey saturates his moments in jail later in life.

These costumes, by James Acheson, enliven the Imperial court with rich reds that bring grandeur to the screen, a sense that’s reinforced by 9,500 extras who appear to be draped in delicately embroidered silk thanks to screen-printed rayon.

results.title: Special effects in Blade Runner (Spinners)
results.brief_description: Blade runner Rick Deckard (Harrison Ford) hunts rogue replicants through the rain-drenched, neon-lit streets of a futuristic Los Angeles in Ridley Scott’s groundbreaking Blade Runner (1982).

constellations_primary.name: The Kubrick connection
constellations_primary.description: The visual effects for Blade Runner drew on a number of techniques from other iconic films, including two of Stanley Kubrick's masterpieces.

results.description:
Blade runner Rick Deckard (Harrison Ford) hunts rogue replicants through the rain-drenched, neon-lit streets of a futuristic Los Angeles in Ridley Scott’s groundbreaking Blade Runner (1982).   

Aside from the influential dystopian setting, Blade Runner is lauded for its striking visual effects, particularly the ‘spinners’ – hi-tech cars that soar through the streets and the sky. Scott was inspired by imagery in several of these books. Futurist and industrial designer Syd Mead also contributed, helping design the sci-fi world around the cars.   

Spinner models were filmed against a black screen and then superimposed on the model shots of LA. Three life-size versions of the spinners were also created. These flew on wires that were later painted out of the shots, while interior shots were filmed against a green screen.
description_for_label:
Blade runner Rick Deckard (Harrison Ford) hunts rogue replicants through the rain-drenched, neon-lit streets of a futuristic Los Angeles in Ridley Scott’s groundbreaking Blade Runner (1982).   

Aside from the influential dystopian setting, Blade Runner is lauded for its striking visual effects, particularly the ‘spinners’ – hi-tech cars that soar through the streets and the sky. Scott was inspired by imagery in several of these books. Futurist and industrial designer Syd Mead also contributed, helping design the sci-fi world around the cars.   

Spinner models were filmed against a black screen and then superimposed on the model shots of LA. Three life-size versions of the spinners were also created. These flew on wires that were later painted out of the shots, while interior shots were filmed against a green screen.

results.title: The Long Tomorrow
results.creator_credit: Les Humanoïdes Associés and Dan O'Bannon
results.brief_description:
Colour printed copy of comic book ‘Moebius - The long tomorrow’, by Les Humanoides Associes; hard cover edition. 56 pages, 21.2 x 29 cm , colour edition
ISBN 9782731673845
results.description: The Long Tomorrow is the title of a science fiction comics short story serialised in two segments in the French magazine Metal Hurlant in 1976. It was written by Dan O’Bannon, and illustrated by Moebius. It is noted for its influential visual design, which inspired the designs of feature films including Tron, Alien, and The Abyss.
description_for_label:
Colour printed copy of comic book ‘Moebius - The long tomorrow’, by Les Humanoides Associes; hard cover edition. 56 pages, 21.2 x 29 cm , colour edition
